'''Language nest'''s, an [[language immersion|immersion]]-based approach to [[language revitalization]], originated in [[New Zealand]] in 1982 as a part of the [[Māori language revival]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/livingthelanguage/2012/04/2012416141630195978.html|title = New Zealand: The Maori|date = July 17, 2014|accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = Al Jazeera|last = |first = }}</ref> The term "language nest" is a translation of the Māori phrase [[Māori language revival#K.C5.8Dhanga reo|''kōhanga reo'']].
In a language nest, older speakers of the language take part in [[early childhood education|early-childhood education]] with a view to improving intergenerational language transference.
== In New Zealand == The first ''kōhanga reo'' was founded in [[Wainuiomata]] in 1982, and was followed by the establishment of primary schools and secondary schools ([[Kura Kaupapa Māori]]) where [[Māori language|Māori]] is the primary language of instruction.
According to Al Jazeera, the percentage of Maori people speaking the language has increased by a few percentage points from the early 1980s to 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/livingthelanguage/2012/04/2012416141630195978.html|title = New Zealand: The Maori|date = July 17, 2014|accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = Al Jazeera|last = |first = }}</ref> Linguist Christopher Moseley says that this statistic is "quite encouraging" because "compared to how quickly a language can disappear, in just one generation in extreme cases, the figures are good."<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/livingthelanguage/2012/04/2012416141630195978.html|title = New Zealand: The Maori|date = July 17, 2014|accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = Al Jazeera|last = |first = }}</ref>
== In the United States == In [[Hawaii]], the [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian-language]] equivalent, the [[Pūnana Leo]], has been running for 24 years<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.culturalsurvival.org/publications/cultural-survival-quarterly/united-states/aha-p-nana-leo|title = ‘Aha Pūnana Leo|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = Cultural Survival|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and has also been successful in producing first-language speakers of Hawaiian.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.ahapunanaleo.org/index.php?/about/a_timeline_of_revitalization/|title = A Timeline of Revitalization|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = Aha Punana Leo|last = |first = }}</ref>
In [[Minnesota]], the Enweyang Ojibwe Language Nest, started in 2009. In collaboration with UMD's College of Education and Human Services Professionals and Eni-gikendaasoyang, the Center for Indigenous Knowledge and [[Language revitalization|Language Revitalization]], the program targets 4-5 year olds in a half day session in the [[Duluth, Minnesota|Duluth]] area.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://d.umn.edu/external-affairs/homepage/10/languagenest.html|title=Enweyang Ojibwe Language Nest|last=|first=|date=|website=University of Minnesota Duluth|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref>
In [[North Dakota]], Lakȟól’yapi Wahóȟpi, the Lakota Language Immersion Nest, opened on September 12, 2012. Full day schooling aimed at 3-year olds, with parents also receiving training to encourage at home efforts is key to this program. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://lastrealindians.com/lakota-language-immersion-nest/|title=Lakota Language Immersion Nest|date=2012-09-10|work=Last Real Indians|access-date=2017-03-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
== In Australia == In August 2009, the [[Australian government]] pledged to pilot language nests as part of its National Indigenous Languages Policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arts.gov.au/indigenous/languages_policy|title=Indigenous Languages Policy}}</ref> The first of five Aboriginal language and culture nests in [[New South Wales]] launched in 2013, although these are government service delivery centres and not immersion pre-schools.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://theconversation.com/language-nests-a-way-to-revive-indigenous-languages-at-risk-19824|title = Language Nests: a way to revive Indigenous languages at risk|date = November 12, 2013|accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = The Conversation|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Aboriginal Language and Culture Nests - Aboriginal Affairs|url = http://www.aboriginalaffairs.nsw.gov.au/aboriginal-language-and-culture-nests/|accessdate = 2015-09-10}}</ref> The [[Miriwoong]] Language Nest has been running in [[Kununurra]] since early 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://soundcloud.com/abcwa/theyre-just-so-proud-to-see-their-grandchildren-learning-their-language|title = They're just so proud to see their grandchildren learning their language|date = |accessdate = March 30, 2015|website = |publisher = ABC Kimberley|last = |first = }}</ref> with over 300 children attending per week.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.mirima.org.au/language-nest.html|title = Language Nest|date = |accessdate = March 30, 2015|website = |publisher = Mirima Dawang Woorlab-gerring Language and Culture Centre|last = |first = }}</ref>
== In Canada == A study in 2004 reported on two language nests in British Columbia: a ''Cseyseten'' ("language nest") at [[Adam’s Lake]] in the [[Secwepemc]] language, and a ''Clao7alcw'' ("Raven’s nest") at [[Lil’wat Nation]] in the [[Lillooet language|Lil’wat]] language written about by [[Onowa McIvor]] for her Master's thesis.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fpcc.ca/files/PDF/language-nest-programs_in_BC.pdf|title = Language Nest programs in BC (MA Thesis)|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = |last = McIvor|first = Onowa}}</ref>
The [[First Peoples' Cultural Council]] in Canada provides grants to [[First Nations]] communities in [[British Columbia]] as part of the Pre-School Language Nest Program.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fpcc.ca/language/Programs/Language-nest.aspx|title = Pre-School Language Nest Program|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = First People's Cultural Council|last = |first = }}</ref>
In the [[Northwest Territories]], there are language nests for each of the official Aboriginal languages, with more than 20 language nests in total.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.ece.gov.nt.ca/early-childhood-and-school-services/early-childhood/language-nests|title = Language Nests|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = Northwest Territories: Education, Culture, and Employment|publisher = Government of the Northwest Territories|last = |first = }}</ref>
==In Estonia==
There is only one language nest for [[Võro language|Võro]] working three days a week in [[Haanja]] and several initiatives, so called "language nest days" (''keelepesäpäiv'') that are working one day in week in 18 different kindergartens of Võro area. Võro language nest initiatives are organised by [[Võro Institute]].
==In Finland==
There are language nests for [[Inari Sami language|Inari Sámi]], [[Skolt Sami language|Skolt Sami]], and the Karelian languages in Finland.

[[File:Loesje ukraine.jpg|thumb|UKRAINE
WHEN DEMOCRACY ISN'T WORKING
PEOPLE ARE]] '''Loesje''' ({{IPAc-en|'|l|uː|ʃ|ə}}; {{IPA-nl|ˈluʃə|lang}}) is an international [[free speech]] [[organisation]] started in [[Arnhem]] ([[Netherlands]]) in 1983 and went international in 1989.[http://www.loesje.org/page/3661 This is Loesje] Its charter is to spread creativity, positive criticism, ideas, philosophical ponderings and thoughts on current events by way of short slogans on [[poster]]s. The posters are signed by Loesje, which is a Dutch female name, representing "a world wide collective of people who want to make the world a more positive creative place".[http://www.loesje.org/page/3661 This is Loesje] Loesje is currently to some extent active in over 30 countries, including [[Argentina]], [[Armenia]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]], [[Belgium]], [[Spain]], [[Denmark]], [[Estonia]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Hungary]], [[Iceland]], [[Italy]], [[Latvia]], [[Lithuania]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Macedonia (country)|Macedonia]], [[Mexico]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Nigeria]], [[Poland]], [[Portugal]], [[Romania]], [[Russia]], [[Serbia]], [[Slovenia]], [[Sweden]], [[Switzerland]], the [[United States|United States of America]], and [[State of Palestine|Palestine]]. In one country it is possible to have several more or less active writing groups. It is not clear how many active writers there are and also the number of people who decide to spread the posters that can be downloaded from the poster archive.[http://www.loesje.org/posterarchive/advanced Poster archive] The organisation cannot hold track of who spreads posters and where, partly because it is impossible to see how often a poster is downloaded (or printed at home) from the website, and partly because Loesje is not responsible for any misdeeds of individuals who paste posters on places where it is illegal.[http://www.loesje.org/node/3456 Sticking law] Between 2005 and 2013, Loesje's international headquarters were located in [[Berlin]], but since then Loesje International has moved back to Arnhem.[http://www.loesje.org/contact Address of Loesje International] From there Loesje implements and coordinates many diverse international projects around the world. Loesje gives creative writing [http://www.loesje.org/page/3671 workshops], for team building for example and joins conferences about issues that connect to her values, such as this environmental conference called [http://www.loesje.org/CEI2012 Caretakers of the environment international] in 2012 in [[Maastricht]] in the Netherlands. Loesje is especially active on [[World Press Freedom Day]]. ==External links== * [http://www.loesje.org Loesje International website] * [http://hdl.handle.net/10622/COLL00310 Collectie posters Loesje] at the [[International Institute of Social History]] Links to websites of specific countries * [http://loesje.org/palestine Loesje Palestine] * [http://www.loesje.org/belgie/ Loesje in Belgium] * [http://www.loesje.ee/ Loesje in Estonia] * [http://www.loesje.fi/ Loesje in Finland] * [http://www.loesje.org/france/ Loesje in France] * [http://www.loesje.de/ Loesje in Germany] * [http://www.loesje.gr/ Loesje in Greece] * [http://www.loesje.ie/ Loesje in Ireland] * [http://www.loesje.org/italy Loesje in Italy] * [http://lv.loesje.org/ Loesje in Latvia] * [http://loesje.lietuvoje.info/ Loesje in Lithuania] * [http://www.loesje.nl Loesje in the Netherlands] * [http://www.loesje.pl Loesje in Poland] * [http://www.loesje.org/portugal/ Loesje in Portugal] * [http://www.loesje.ru/ Loesje in Russia ] * [http://www.loesje.org.yu/ Loesje in Serbia] * [http://loesje.slo.net/ Loesje in Slovenia] * [http://www.loesje.se/ Loesje in Sweden] {{commons category|Loesje}} {{wikiquote}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Freedom of expression]]

'''Logotherapy''' was developed by [[Neurology|neurologist]] and [[psychiatrist]] [[Viktor Frankl]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/open-future/2018/08/24/proper-palliative-care-makes-assisted-dying-unnecessary|title=Proper palliative care makes assisted dying unnecessary|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}} It is considered the "Third Viennese School of [[Psychotherapy]]"{{cite book|author= Frankl, Viktor|title=Man's Search for Meaning|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F-Q_xGjWBi8C|accessdate=8 May 2012|date=1 June 2006|publisher=Beacon Press|isbn=978-0-8070-1427-1}}[[Gordon Allport]], from the Preface to ''[[Man's Search for Meaning]]'', p. xiv along with [[Sigmund Freud|Freud's]] [[psychoanalysis]] and [[Alfred Adler|Adler's]] [[individual psychology]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/320814.php|title=Logotherapy: The benefits of finding meaning in life|work=Medical News Today|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}} Logotherapy is based on an [[Existential therapy|existential analysis]]{{cite web|last=|first=|title=About Logotherapy|publisher=Viktor Frankl Institute Vienna|url=http://www.viktorfrankl.org/e/logotherapy.html|accessdate=22 May 2012}} focusing on [[Kierkegaard]]'s ''[[Meaning (existential)|will to meaning]]'' as opposed to Adler's [[Nietzsche]]an doctrine of ''[[will to power]]'' or Freud's ''[[Pleasure principle (psychology)|will to pleasure]]''. Rather than power or pleasure, logotherapy is founded upon the belief that striving to find meaning in life is the primary, most powerful motivating and driving force in [[human]]s.{{cite book|author1=Maria Marshall|author2=Edward Marshall|title=Logotherapy Revisited: Review of the Tenets of Viktor E. Frankl's Logotherapy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gnZxPpqDjUUC|accessdate=|date=4 August 2012|publisher=Ottawa Institute of Logotherapy|isbn=978-1-4781-9377-7}} A short introduction to this system is given in Frankl's most famous book, ''[[Man's Search for Meaning]]'', in which he outlines how his theories helped him to survive his [[Holocaust]] experience and how that experience further developed and reinforced his theories. Presently, there are a number of [[List of logotherapy institutes|logotherapy institutes]] around the world. ==Basic principles== The notion of ''Logotherapy'' was created with the [[Greek language|Greek]] word ''[[logos]]'' ("reason"). Frankl’s concept is based on the premise that the primary motivational force of an individual is to find a meaning in life. The following list of tenets represents basic principles of logotherapy: * Life has meaning under all circumstances, even the most miserable ones. * Our main motivation for living is our will to find meaning in life. * We have freedom to find meaning in what we do, and what we experience, or at least in the stance we take when faced with a situation of unchangeable suffering. The human spirit is referred to in several of the assumptions of logotherapy, but the use of the term spirit is not "spiritual" or "religious". In Frankl's view, the spirit is the will of the human being. The emphasis, therefore, is on the search for meaning, which is not necessarily the search for [[God]] or any other supernatural being. Frankl also noted the barriers to humanity's quest for meaning in life. He warns against "...affluence, [[hedonism]], [and] [[Economic materialism|materialism]]..." in the search for meaning.{{cite web|last=|first=|title=About Logotherapy|publisher=Viktor Frankl Institute of Logotherapy|url=http://www.logotherapyinstitute.org/About_Logotherapy.html|accessdate=22 May 2012}} Purpose in life and [[Meaning of life|meaning in life]] constructs appeared in Frankl's logotherapy writings with relation to [[existential vacuum]] and will to meaning, as well as others who have theorized about and defined [[Positive psychology|positive psychological]] functioning. Frankl observed that it may be psychologically damaging when a person's search for meaning is blocked. Positive life purpose and meaning was associated with strong religious beliefs, membership in groups, dedication to a cause, life values, and clear goals. Adult development and [[maturity (psychological)|maturity]] theories include the purpose in life concept. Maturity emphasizes a clear comprehension of life's purpose, directedness, and intentionality which contributes to the feeling that life is meaningful.{{cite web | last = Adler | first = Nancy | authorlink = | title = Purpose in Life | work = Psychosocial workgroup | publisher = MacArthur Foundation | date = November 1997 | url = http://www.macses.ucsf.edu/research/psychosocial/purpose.php | accessdate = 2011-11-03}} Frankl's ideas were operationalized by Crumbaugh and Maholick's Purpose in Life (PIL) test, which measures an individual's meaning and purpose in life. With the test, investigators found that meaning in life mediated the relationships between religiosity and well-being;{{cite journal | last = Dufton | first = Brian | authorlink = | title = The association between religiosity and the Purpose-in-Life test: Does it reflect purpose or satisfaction? | journal = Journal of Psychology and Theology | volume = 14 | issue = 1 | pages = 42–48 | publisher = Biola University | date = Spring 1986 | url = http://journals.biola.edu/jpt/volumes/14/issues/1/articles/42|accessdate =}} uncontrollable stress and substance use; depression and self-derogation.{{cite journal | last =Harlow | first = Lisa L. | authorlink = |author2=Newcomb, Michael D. |author3=Bentler, P. M | title = Purpose in Life Test assessment using latent variable methods. | journal = British Journal of Clinical Psychology | volume = 26 | issue = 3 | pages = 235–236 | publisher = | location = | date = Sep 1987 | url = | doi= 10.1111/j.2044-8260.1987.tb01355.x}} Crumbaugh found that the Seeking of [[Nous|Noetic]] Goals Test (SONG) is a complementary measure of the PIL. While the PIL measures the presence of meaning, the SONG measures orientation towards meaning. A low score in the PIL but a high score in the SONG, would predict a better outcome in the application of Logotherapy.{{cite journal | last = Crumbaugh | first = James C. | authorlink = | title = The seeking of noetic goals test (SONG): A complementary scale to the purpose in life test (PIL) | journal = Journal of Clinical Psychology | volume = 33 | issue = 3 | pages = 900–907 | publisher = Wiley | location = | date = July 1977 | doi = 10.1002/1097-4679(197707)33:3<900::AID-JCLP2270330362>3.0.CO;2-8 }} ===Discovering meaning=== According to Frankl, "We can discover this meaning in life in three different ways: (1) by creating a work or doing a deed; (2) by experiencing something or encountering someone; and (3) by the attitude we take toward unavoidable suffering" and that "everything can be taken from a man but one thing: the last of the human freedoms – to choose one's attitude in any given set of circumstances". On the meaning of suffering, Frankl gives the following example:
"Once, an elderly general practitioner consulted me because of his severe depression. He could not overcome the loss of his wife who had died two years before and whom he had loved above all else. Now how could I help him? What should I tell him? I refrained from telling him anything, but instead confronted him with a question, "What would have happened, Doctor, if you had died first, and your wife would have had to survive without you?:" "Oh," he said, "for her this would have been terrible; how she would have suffered!" Whereupon I replied, "You see, Doctor, such a suffering has been spared her, and it is you who have spared her this suffering; but now, you have to pay for it by surviving and mourning her." He said no word but shook my hand and calmly left the office.{{rp|178–179}}
Frankl emphasized that realizing the value of suffering is meaningful only when the first two creative possibilities are not available (for example, in a concentration camp) and only when such suffering is inevitable{{spaced ndash}}he was not proposing that people suffer unnecessarily.{{cite book|author= Frankl, Viktor|title=The Doctor and the Soul: From Psychotherapy to Logotherapy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v_qiURM2r2MC|accessdate=17 May 2012|date=12 October 1986|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|isbn=978-0-394-74317-2}}{{rp|115}} ==Philosophical basis of logotherapy== Frankl described the meta-clinical implications of logotherapy in his book ''The Will to Meaning: Foundations and Applications of Logotherapy''.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/934802526|title=The will to meaning : foundations and applications of logotherapy|last=1905-1997,|first=Frankl, Viktor E. (Viktor Emil),|isbn=9781101664025|edition= Expanded |location=New York, New York|oclc=934802526}} He believed that there is no psychotherapy apart from the theory of man. As an existential psychologist, he inherently disagreed with the “machine model” or “rat model”, as it undermines the human quality of humans. As a neurologist and psychiatrist, Frankl developed a unique view of [[determinism]] to coexist with the three basic pillars of logotherapy (the freedom of will). Though Frankl admitted that man can never be free from every condition, such as, biological, sociological, or psychological determinants, based on his experience during his life in the Nazi concentration camps, he believed that man is “capable of resisting and braving even the worst conditions”. In doing such, man can detach from situations, himself, choose an attitude about himself, determine his own determinants, thus shaping his own character and becoming responsible for himself.{{cite book|author= Frankl, Viktor|title=The Will to Meaning: Foundations and Applications of Logotherapy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5gImYTIc7BcC|accessdate=17 May 2012|date=1 September 1988|publisher=Meridian|isbn=978-0-452-01034-5}} ==Logotherapeutic views and treatment== ===Overcoming anxiety=== By recognizing the purpose of our circumstances, one can master anxiety. Anecdotes about this use of logotherapy are given by ''New York Times'' writer Tim Sanders, who explained how he uses its concept to relieve the stress of fellow airline travelers by asking them the purpose of their journey. When he does this, no matter how miserable they are, their whole demeanor changes, and they remain happy throughout the flight.{{cite news|last=Sanders|first=Tim|title=A Chatterer's Guide to Easing Anxiety|publisher=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/27/travel/27iht-25flier.18204176.html|accessdate=|date=27 October 2008}} Overall, Frankl believed that the anxious individual does not understand that his anxiety is the result of dealing with a sense of “unfulfilled responsibility” and ultimately a lack of meaning.{{cite web|last=Boeree|first=C. George|title=Viktor Frankl|publisher=Shippensburg University|url=http://webspace.ship.edu/cgboer/frankl.html|year=2006|accessdate=}} ===Treatment of neurosis=== Frankl cites two neurotic pathogens: hyper-intention, a forced intention toward some end which makes that end unattainable; and hyper-reflection, an excessive attention to oneself which stifles attempts to avoid the [[neurosis]] to which one thinks oneself predisposed. Frankl identified [[anticipatory anxiety]], a fear of a given outcome which makes that outcome more likely. To relieve the anticipatory anxiety and treat the resulting neuroses, logotherapy offers [[paradoxical intention]], wherein the patient intends to do the opposite of their hyper-intended goal. A person, then, who fears (i.e. experiences anticipatory anxiety over) not getting a good night's sleep may try too hard (that is, hyper-intend) to fall asleep, and this would hinder their ability to do so. A logotherapist would recommend, then, that the person go to bed and intentionally try not to fall asleep. This would relieve the anticipatory anxiety which kept the person awake in the first place, thus allowing them to fall asleep in an acceptable amount of time. ===Depression=== Viktor Frankl believed depression occurred at the psychological, physiological, and spiritual levels. At the psychological level, he believed that feelings of inadequacy stem from undertaking tasks beyond our abilities. At the physiological level, he recognized a “vital low”, which he defined as a “diminishment of physical energy”. Finally, Frankl believed that at the spiritual level, the depressed man faces tension between who he actually is in relation to what he should be. Frankl refers to this as the gaping abyss.{{rp|202}} Finally Frankl suggests that if goals seem unreachable, an individual loses a sense of future and thus meaning resulting in depression. Thus logotherapy aims “to change the patient’s attitude toward their disease as well as toward their life as a task”.{{rp|200}} ===Obsessive-compulsive disorder=== Frankl believed that those suffering from obsessive-compulsive disorder lack the sense of completion that most other individuals possess. Instead of fighting the tendencies to repeat thoughts or actions, or focusing on changing the individual symptoms of the disease, the therapist should focus on “transform[ing] the neurotic’s attitude toward their neurosis”.{{rp|185}} Therefore, it is important to recognize that the patient is “not responsible for his obsessional ideas”, but that “he is certainly responsible for his attitude toward these ideas”.{{rp|188}} Frankl suggested that it is important for the patient to recognize his inclinations toward perfection as fate, and therefore, must learn to accept some degrees of uncertainty. Ultimately, following the premise of logotherapy, the patient must eventually ignore his obsessional thoughts and find meaning in his life despite such thoughts. ===Schizophrenia=== Though logotherapy wasn’t intended to deal with severe disorders, Frankl believed that logotherapy could benefit even those suffering from schizophrenia. He recognized the roots of schizophrenia in physiological dysfunction. In this dysfunction, the person with schizophrenia “experiences himself as an object” rather than as a subject.{{rp|208}} Frankl suggested that a person with schizophrenia could be helped by logotherapy by first being taught to ignore voices and to end persistent self-observation. Then, during this same period, the person with schizophrenia must be led toward meaningful activity, as “even for the schizophrenic there remains that residue of freedom toward fate and toward the disease which man always possesses, no matter how ill he may be, in all situations and at every moment of life, to the very last”.{{rp|216}} ===Terminally ill patients=== In 1977, Terry Zuehlke and John Watkins conducted a study analyzing the effectiveness of logotherapy in treating terminally ill patients. The study’s design used 20 male Veterans Administration volunteers who were randomly assigned to one of two possible treatments – (1) group that received 8-45 minute sessions over a 2 week period and (2) group used as control that received delayed treatment. Each group was tested on 5 scales – the [[Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory|MMPI K Scale]], MMPI L Scale, Death Anxiety Scale, Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale, and the Purpose of Life Test. The results showed an overall significant difference between the control and treatment groups. While the univariate analyses showed that there were significant group differences in 3/5 of the dependent measures. These results confirm the idea that terminally ill patients can benefit from logotherapy in coping with death.{{cite journal|last=Zuehlke|first=T.E.|author2=Watkins, J.T. |title=Psychotherapy with Terminally Ill Patients|journal=Psychotherapy, Therapy, Research, and Practice|year=1977|volume=14|issue=4|pages=403–410|doi=10.1037/h0087512}} ==Controversy== {{See also|Psychotherapy#General critiques}} ===Authoritarianism=== In 1969 [[Rollo May]] argued that logotherapy is, in essence, [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]]. He suggested that Frankl’s therapy presents a plain solution to all of life’s problems, an assertion that would seem to undermine the complexity of human life itself. May contended that if a patient could not find his own meaning, Frankl would provide a goal for his patient. In effect, this would negate the patient’s personal responsibility, thus “diminish[ing] the patient as a person”.{{cite book|author=Rollo May|title=Existential psychology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BWRZHZrR4IYC|accessdate=21 May 2012|year=1969|publisher=Random House|page=42}} (First Edition 1961) Frankl explicitly replied to May’s arguments through a written dialogue, sparked by Rabbi [[Reuven Bulka]]’s article “Is Logotherapy Authoritarian?”.{{cite journal | last = Bulka | first =Reuven P. | title = Is Logotherapy Authoritarian? | journal = Journal of Humanistic Psychology | volume = 18 | issue = 4 | pages = 45–54 | date = Fall 1978 | doi =10.1177/002216787801800406 | accessdate = }} Frankl responded that he combined the prescription of medication, if necessary, with logotherapy, to deal with the person's psychological and emotional reaction to the illness, and highlighted areas of freedom and responsibility, where the person is free to search and to find meaning.{{cite journal | last = Frankl | first =Viktor | title = Reply to Rollo May | journal = Journal of Humanistic Psychology | volume = 19 | issue = 4 | pages = 85–86 | date = Fall 1979 | doi =10.1177/002216787901900410 }} ===Religiousness=== Critical views of the life of logotherapy's founder and his work assume that Frankl's religious background and experience of suffering guided his conception of meaning within the boundaries of the person{{cite journal|last=Pytell|first=T.|title=Transcending the Angel Beast: Viktor Frankl and Humanistic Psychology|journal=Psychoanalytic Psychology|year=2006|volume=23|issue=3|pages=490–503|doi=10.1037/0736-9735.23.3.490}} and therefore that logotherapy is founded on Viktor Frankl's worldview.{{cite journal|last=Pytell|first=T.|title=Extreme Experience, Psychological Insight, and Holocaust Perception: Reflections on Bettelheim and Frankl|journal=Psychoanalytic Psychology|year=2007|volume=24|issue=4|pages=641–657|doi=10.1037/0736-9735.24.4.641}} Frankl openly spoke and wrote on religion and psychiatry, throughout his life, and specifically in his last book, ''Man’s Search for Ultimate Meaning'' (1997). He asserted that every person has a spiritual unconscious, independently of religious views or beliefs, yet Frankl's conception of the spiritual unconscious does not necessarily entail religiosity. In Frankl's words: “It is true, Logotherapy, deals with the Logos; it deals with Meaning. Specifically, I see Logotherapy in helping others to see meaning in life. But we cannot “give” meaning to the life of others. And if this is true of meaning per se, how much does it hold for Ultimate Meaning?”{{cite book|author=Frankl, Viktor|title=Man's search for ultimate meaning|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_hcQAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=10 May 2012|date=10 August 2000|publisher=Perseus Pub.|isbn=978-0-7382-0354-6}} The [[American Psychiatric Association]] awarded Viktor Frankl the 1985 [[Oskar Pfister Award]] (for important contributions to religion and psychiatry). ===Origins=== On Frankl's doctrine that one must instill meaning in the events in ones life, that work and suffering to find meaning, will ultimately lead to fulfillment and happiness. In 1982 the highly cited scholar and holocaust analyst [[Lawrence L. Langer]], who while also critical of Frankl's distortions on the true experience of those at Auschwitz,[Suicide Prohibition: The Shame of Medicine By Thomas Szasz. pg 60-62] and Frankl's amoral focus on "meaning" that could just as equally be applied to Nazis "finding meaning in making the world free from Jews",[Suicide Prohibition: The Shame of Medicine By Thomas Szasz pg 62] Langer would go on to write: "If this [logotherapy] doctrine had been more succinctly worded, the Nazis might have substituted it for the cruel mockery of [[Arbeit Macht Frei]] [the sign chosen to be placed over the entry to Auschwitz]".[Lawrence Langer, Versions of Survival: The Holocaust and the Human Spirit (Albany: State University of New York Press, 1982), p.24. [End Page 107]] A biographer of Frankl would later remark on the penetrating insight of Langer's reading of Frankl's holocaust testimony, with Langer's criticism published in 1982 before ther biographer's research, the former had thus drawn the controversial parallels, or accommodations in ideology without the knowledge that Victor Frankl was an advocate/"embraced"Austrian Lives By Günter Bischof pg 241-242 the key ideas of the [[Matthias Goring|Nazi psychotherapy]] movement ("will and responsibility"Viktor Frankl's Search for Meaning: An Emblematic 20th-Century Life By Timothy Pytell pg 70-72, 111) as a form of therapy in the late 1930s. When at that time Frankl would submit a paper and contributed to the [[Matthias Göring|Göring institute]] in Vienna 1937 and again in early 1938 connecting the logotherapy focus on "world-view" to the "work of some of the leading Nazi psychotherapists",Austrian Lives By Günter Bischof pg 242 both at a time before [[Anschluss|Austria was annexed by Nazi Germany in 1938]].Austrian Lives By Günter Bischof p.255[http://muse.jhu.edu/article/43137#REF104 "What is perhaps most impressive about Langer's reading is that he was unaware of Frankl's 1937 article promoting a form of psychotherapy palatable to the Nazis".] The origins of logotherapy, as described by Frankl, were therefore a major issue of continuity that Biographer Pytell argues were potentially problematic for Frankl because he had laid out the main elements of logotherapy while working for/contributing to the Nazi-affiliated Göring Institute. Principally Frankl's 1937 paper, that was published by the institute.[http://muse.jhu.edu/article/43137#REF104 "What is perhaps most impressive about Langer's reading is that he was unaware of Frankl's 1937 article promoting a form of psychotherapy palatable to the Nazis".] This association, as a source of controversy, that logotherapy was palatable to [[National Socialism]] is the reason Pytell suggests, Frankl took two different stances on how the concentration-camp experience affected the course of his psychotherapy theory. Namely, that within the original English edition of Frankl's most well known book, ''Man's Search for Meaning'', the suggestion is made and still largely held that logotherapy was itself derived from his camp experience, with the claim as it appears in the original edition, that this form of psychotherapy was "not concocted in the philosopher's armchair nor at the analyst's couch; it took shape in the hard school of air-raid shelters and bomb craters; in concentration camps and prisoner of war camps." Frankl's statements however to this effect would be deleted from later editions, though in the 1963 edition, a similar statement again appeared on the back of the book jacket of ''Man's Search for Meaning''. Frankl over the years would switch between the claim that logotherapy took shape in the camps to the claim that the camps merely justified his already preconceived theories, as the definitive word on the matter, in 1977 Frankl himself began to clarify the controversy stating "People think I came out of Auschwitz with a brand-new psychotherapy. This is not the case."["http://muse.jhu.edu/article/43137 Redeeming the Unredeemable:Auschwitz and Man's Search for Meaning, Timothy E. Pytell, California State University. Holocaust and Genocide Studies, Volume 17, Number 1, Spring 2003 Oxford University Press] == Recent developments == Since the 1990s, logotherapy has evolved into meaning therapy.Wong, P. T. P. (1997). Meaning-centered counselling: A cognitive-behavioral approach to logotherapy. ''The International Forum for Logotherapy, 20''(2), 85-94.Wong, P. T. P. (2012). From logotherapy to meaning-centered counseling and therapy. In P. T. P. Wong (Ed.), ''The human quest for meaning: Theories, research, and applications'' (2nd ed., pp. 619-647). New York, NY: Routledge. [[Paul T. P. Wong|Wong]] attempted to translate logotherapy into psychological mechanisms in order to make it more relevant to the wider psychology community.Wong, P. T. P. (2014). Viktor Frankl’s meaning seeking model and positive psychology. In A. Batthyany & P. Russo-Netzer (Eds.), ''Meaning in existential and positive psychology'' (pp. 149-184)''.'' New York, NY: Springer.Wong, P. T. P. (2016). Integrative meaning therapy: From logotherapy to existential positive interventions. In P. Russo-Netzer, S. E. Schulenberg, & A. Batthyany (Eds.). ''To thrive, to cope, to understand: Meaning in positive and existential psychotherapy'' (pp. 0-0). New York, NY: Springer. This extension not only integrates meaning therapy with [[cognitive behavioral therapy]] and [[positive psychotherapy]], but also connects meaning therapy with the [[positive psychology]] research on meaning. Another new development is the application of logotherapy to palliative care.Breitbart, W. S. & Poppet, S. R. (2014). ''Meaning-centered group psychotherapy for patients with advanced cancer: A treatment manual.'' New York, NY: Oxford.Breitbart, W. S. & Poppet, S. R. (2014). ''Individual meaning-centered psychotherapy for patients with advanced cancer: A treatment manual.'' New York, NY: Oxford. These recent developments introduce Viktor Frankl's logotherapy to a new generation and extend its impact to new areas of research.Batthyany, A., & Russo-Netzer, P. (2014). Meaning in positive and existential psychology. New York, NY: Springer. ==Locations== A number of logotherapeutic institutes have opened up in various countries around the world and include: {{Div col}} ===Africa=== * Viktor Frankl Institute of South Africa[http://www.vfisa.co.za/ Viktor Frankl Institute of South Africa] ===Asia=== * The Viktor Frankl Center for Logotherapy in Israel[http://www.otsmot.com/english/index.htm The Viktor Frankl Center for Logotherapy in Israel] ===Europe=== * Viktor Frankl Institute - Vienna, Austria[http://www.viktorfrankl.org/ Viktor Frankl Institute - Vienna, Austria] * Viktor Frankl Institute of Ireland[https://web.archive.org/web/20140606212900/http://www.logotherapyireland.com/ Viktor Frankl Institute of Ireland] * Logotherapy Institute of Finland[http://logoterapia.fi/cmsms/index.php?page=in-english Logotherapy Institute of Finland] * Viktor Frankl Institute of Logotherapy - Prague, Czech Republic[http://www.expats.cz/prague/czech/universities/viktorfranklinstituteforlogotherapy/ Viktor Frankl Institute of Logotherapy - Prague, Czech Republic] ===North America=== * Viktor Frankl Institute of Logotherapy - Abilene, Texas[http://www.logotherapyinstitute.org/ Viktor Frankl Institute of Logotherapy - Abilene, Texas] * Arizona Institute of Logotherapy[http://logotherapy.us/ Arizona Institute of Logotherapy] * Canadian Institute of Logotherapy - The main components of automobile exhaust are [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>) and water vapor (H<sub>2</sub>O). Carbon dioxide is the most important [[human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] [[greenhouse gas]] (GHG) and the most significant [[Greenhouse Gas]] emitted in the U.S. (with 82-84% of all U.S. emissions).<ref>[http://www.greenbuilder.com/sbc/newsletters/99july.html July 1999 SBC Newsletter<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070427125401/http://www.greenbuilder.com/sbc/newsletters/99july.html |date=2007-04-27 }}</ref> Increases in carbon dioxide concentration are due primarily to [[fossil fuel]] use and [[land-use]] change.<ref>[[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|IPCC]], ''{{cite web|url= http://www.20minutos.es/data/adj/2007/02/02/456.pdf |title=Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis }} {{small|(2.20 [[Mebibyte|MiB]])}}'' .</ref>
The CO<sub>2</sub> emission standards can be referred to the [[fuel]] or to the [[vehicle]] :
*The [[European Union]] is moving towards fuel mandatory CO<sub>2</sub> standards and USA has reflected it in the [[Greenhouse Gas Score]]. *There are information, but no mandatory, standards for CO<sub>2</sub> limits in vehicle (engine) emissions, excepting some state regulations (i.e. California). See [[hybrid vehicles]].
CO<sub>2</sub> mass emission in vehicles is measured in '''g/km''' (g/[[mile|mi]] * 0.621371192 = g/km).
== Low carbon fuel standard == Transportation accounts for forty percent of California's annual [[greenhouse gas emission]]s, and California relies on [[petroleum-based fuel]]s for 96 percent of its transportation needs.
The [[Californian Governor]] [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] issued an [[Executive order (United States)|Executive Order]] in January 2007 for California adopt a [[Low-carbon fuel standard|Low-Carbon Fuel Standard]] (LCFS).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gov.ca.gov/index.php?/press-release/5074|title= Gov. Schwarzenegger Issues Directive to Establish World's First Low Carbon Standard for Transportation Fuels|publisher=Press Release by [[Arnold Schwarzenegger#Governor of California|Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger]] |date=2007-01-07 |accessdate=2009-04-23}}</ref> The LCFS requires [[oil refinery|oil refineries]] to ensure that the mix of fuel they sell in the California Market meets, on average, a declining target for [[greenhouse gas]] emissions measured in [[carbon dioxide equivalent|CO<sub>2</sub>-equivalent]] grams per unit of fuel energy sold. By 2020, the LCFS will produce a '''10 %''' reduction in carbon intensity from production and use of transport fuels in California.<ref name="CARB01">{{cite web|url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/lcfs.htm|title=Low-Carbon Fuel Standard Program|publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]]|accessdate=2009-04-23}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Emission standard]] * [[Low-carbon economy]] * [[Sustainable mobility technology]]
==References== <references />

'''MODELISAR''' was an ITEA 2 (Information Technology for European Advancement)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.itea2.org/ | title=Welcome to ITEA 2 | publisher=itea2.org | accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> European project aiming to improve the design of systems and of embedded software in vehicles.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.modelisar.com/modelisar.html |title = Project Profile |publisher = modelisar.com |accessdate = 2012-01-29 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120328054431/http://www.modelisar.com/modelisar.html |archivedate = 2012-03-28 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.itea2.org/project/index/view/?project=217 |title = MODELISAR |publisher = itea2.org |quote = ''The purpose of MODELISAR has been to introduce functional mock-up (FMU), a next generation of methods, standards and tools to support collaborative design, simulation and test of systems and embedded software'' |accessdate = 2012-01-29 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120710041444/http://www.itea2.org/project/index/view/?project=217 |archivedate = 2012-07-10 |df = }}</ref> The MODELISAR goals were to: * Support the [[AUTOSAR]] (AUTomotive Open System ARchitecture) standard (AUTOSAR is a [[standardized]] [[automotive software]] architecture) * Develop the [[Functional Mock-up Interface]] standardized interface
The MODELISAR project started in 2008 , ended Dec 2011 to define the [[Functional Mock-up Interface]] specifications, deliver technology studies, prove the FMI concepts through Use Cases elaborated by the consortium partners and enable tool vendors to build advanced prototypes or in some cases even products. MODELISAR has been awarded during ITEA 2 & ARTEMIS co summit with a Silver award. See [https://web.archive.org/web/20120905081532/http://www.itea2.org/cosummit2012_achievementaward ITEA 2 achievement award]
Although in MODELISAR the focus was driven by automotive Use Cases, the FMI specifications could be independently defined. Therefore the FMI can now address others industrial domains such as Energy, Aerospace, Rail.
==See also== * [[Functional Mock-up Interface]] * [[AUTOSAR]]

'''Management due diligence''' is the process of appraising a company's [[senior management]]—evaluating each individual's effectiveness in contributing to the organization's [[Strategic management|strategic objectives]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Management Audit|url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/management-audit.asp|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref>
Assessing company management is crucial when closing business deals. It can mean the difference between long-term success or sudden failure. It also helps the organisation understand how the teams perform their roles in context with the company's future business plan. This helps clarify the structure of the organisation's work-force.<ref name="Best practice">{{cite web|title=Best practice guideline- Due Diligence|url=http://www.crelos.com/assets/Human-capital-due-diligence-the-assessment-and-development-of-management-teams.pdf|accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="good manager">{{cite web|title=What makes a good manager|url=http://www.mas.org.uk/management-advisory-service/what-makes-a-good-manager.html|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> The management due diligence process can be identified as an informative tool for external stakeholders, and can also be referred to as Management Assessment as it addresses the team’s dynamics and highlight the risks.<ref name=Assessment>{{cite web|title=Assessment and development- Management Due Diligence|url=http://www.ashleyhoyle.co.uk/leadership_development_consulting/due_diligence_management.aspx|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref>
== Management assessment ==
Management assessment usually focuses on assessing the leadership skills and characteristics of the organisation's managers—such as the ability to adjust to a changing environment<ref>{{cite web|title=Senior management|url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/senior-management.html|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> and communicate effectively with other individuals. These characteristics are key points in successful leaders.<ref name="good manager"/>
A leader must consider all factors concerning a strategic decision, such as possible effects on employees and customers. Engaging employees and customers in the decision process helps build better relationships.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Five characteristics of great leaders|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3004914/5-characteristics-great-leaders|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref>
==Transactions that require management due diligence== Companies typically apply the due diligence process when they are about to engage in a major transaction with another company—such as selling or purchasing products or services, or buying (merging with or acquiring) the other company.<ref name="What is">{{cite web|title=What is Due Diligence and how do you perform it?|url=http://www.businessknowhow.com/money/duediligence.htm|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> Some transactions require a due diligence report that includes managements.<ref name=Meaning>{{cite web|title=Meaning of due diligence|url=http://www.jsandco.in/Uploaded%20Image/Due%20diligence.pdf|accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref> Transactions that might require managerial assessments include:
=== Mergers, acquisitions and strategic alliances === Organizations considering a merger, acquisition or alliance should perform due diligence. This due diligence should investigate the other party's management team. Many mergers and acquisitions fail because of human resources and management-related issues, such as cultural clashes. These incidents occur because of different cultural values or different individual beliefs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Merger Due Diligence- The devil in details|url=http://www.workforce.com/articles/merger-due-diligence-the-devil-in-the-details|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> To avoid such incidents, and cut costs on the long run, management teams must be assessed thoroughly.<ref name=Meaning/>
=== Partnerships === Before organizations signs a partnership contract, they must investigate the other organization’s matters and affiliations, organizational structures, and behaviors. A management due diligence process achieves this.
=== Joint ventures and collaborations === When forming a relationship with another organizations, management due diligence helps an organization introduce management structure the behavior of individuals.<ref name=Meaning/>
=== Management due diligence's responsibility === Not only buyers carry out management due diligence, but also sellers of an organization. Usually, the process of selling an organization or adopting any external growth strategies requires the sharing of warranties. These warranties require private information from the organization—possibly including information and activities that they must shield from the view of third parties. In this case, the seller should carry out due diligence to ensure secure data.<ref name=Meaning/>
==Importance== Management due diligence ensures sustainable profit and growth for organisations, as it identifies the human capital components. It ensures that highly skilled people are assigned the correct jobs and responsibilities.<ref name="Best practice"/> It increases the chance of a good return on investment by reducing risk.<ref name=Assessment/>
Management due diligence identifies strengths and weaknesses of individuals in the management team and assesses their contributions to the organisation.<ref name="Best practice"/> It assesses management team members' abilities to reach common goals.<ref name=Firefly>{{cite web|title=Management Due Diligence|url=http://www.fireflypartners.co.uk/mngmentduediligence.html|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref>
It identifies undiscovered dangers that eventually affect productivity. These might include unacknowledged motives or personal conflicts between individuals in management.<ref>{{cite web|title=Due Diligence- The management team aspect: who's driving your company|url=http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/contributors.asp?id=803|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> It helps organizations efficiently appraise candidates for a management team position.<ref name=Firefly/>
Management due diligence gives an organization a basis for expectations for team and individual performance. Accordingly, the organization can determine whether managers need training.<ref>{{cite web|title=Performance appraisal for teams|url=https://www.opm.gov/policy-data-oversight/performance-management/reference-materials/historical/teams.pdf|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref>
==Process== Since management due diligence lies in the financial analysis of a due diligence report,<ref>{{cite web|title=Due Diligence|url=http://www.icaew.com/en/members/business-resources/business-management-and-strategy/m-and-a/types-of-due-diligence|accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref> It shares the same process as creating a due diligence report with few variations.
===Preparation=== Preparation is key to an effective management due diligence process. In this phase, organizations gain sufficient knowledge about other organizations. This helps them decide on communication methods between them and other entities, in addition to putting resources in place to promote a successful process. After settling those issues, the organization must:
''Form a team for the analysis process'' from skilled people with enough experience. After forming the team, the organization assigns responsibilities and settles on a process timeline. The organization may fill gaps in expertise by hiring or contracting external people.
''Involve managers'' as early as possible''' as they must get to know the other organization's management team. Early introductions help managers deal with later obstacles.
''Create checklists'' tailored to particular risks associated with the other organization.
''Prepare a list of data requests'' for the information an organization needs to complete the process.<ref name="Main steps"/> Such data could include the business plan's management team section,<ref>{{cite web|title=Due Diligence information request|url=http://www.stevensonco.com/documents/Due-Diligence-Information-Request-Sample.pdf|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> or management organizational structure.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sample Due Diligence request list|url=http://www.theventurealley.com/files/2013/08/Sample-due-diligence-request-list-Trent-Dykes.pd_1.pdf|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref>
''After negotiations, have both parties sign a confidentiality report'' to protect sensitive data from third parties. Agree on a method to store all confidential data—for example, an online data repository<ref name="Main steps"/> that both parties can view.<ref>{{cite web|title=Virtual Data Room|url=http://www.webopedia.com/TERM/V/Virtual_Data_Room.html|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref>
===Execution=== In this phase the organization begins analyzing gathered data. The team tries to confirm the target's representations and "soft" aspects of the target, such as its corporate culture. The team must make sure the other organization fits with its own after assessing their management quality. After gathering all the information, the team advises on whether their organization should continue to work with the other organization.
===Closure=== After the team finishes analyzing the management team, they submit a report to the final decision makers. If the team exposes irregularities or unexpected risks, the organization can bid on contract changes. If everything passes the assessment, team members switch to integration planning.<ref name="Main steps"/>
==Aspects== By performing management due diligence to assess the individuals working in an organization, different aspects must be appraised. The diagram outlines the main aspects that must be evaluated. The four circles in the middle represent the basic qualities that are considered essential for an individual assessment. The bigger circle "Role" represents the duties of the individuals in a certain organization. These duties usually vary from one individual to another depending on the job description of that individual. The biggest circle representing the employing organization is located in a market, making it easy to get affected by various external factors.<ref name="Best practice"/> These external factors are capable of hindering the organization from achieving its strategic goals and long-term objectives, making this a challenge that has to be dealt with.<ref>{{cite web|title=External Factors|url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/external-factors.html|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref>
For the individual assessment to be precise and accurate, it must be done after the organization's requirements have been highlighted and responsibilities of each individual are clear. Having such knowledge helps the business organization overcome future challenges and move closer to strategic objectives.<ref name="Best practice"/>
==Key points== Management due diligence needs: *Clear, defined objectives—set expectations in terms of management styles and qualities in individuals * Commitment—assess whether management resources can make the business succeed.<ref name=Meaning/> * Assess strengths—recognize strengths of individual members to use them effectively The management team is an asset to any organisation,<ref name="most important">{{cite web|title=The most important assets are not on the balance sheet|url=http://www.triplepundit.com/2010/09/the-most-important-assets-are-not-on-the-balance-sheet/|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref>
==Limitations and drawbacks==
To assure reliable data, both investor and individuals under assessment must be involved in the feedback process. This can be costly and time-consuming to both parties. Since due diligence can be a detective game, organizations must find individuals who can detect small issues and opportunities. Organizations sometimes bring in outside experts.<ref name="Main steps">{{cite web|title=Due Diligence: Main steps and success factors|url=http://www.gecapital.eu/en/docs/GE_Capital_Overview_Due_Diligence.pdf|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref>
The expense of the due diligence process, and the time involved, can be softened by dividing it into two stages.<ref>{{cite web|title=PRELIMINARY DUE DILIGENCE (This is the 9th article in the series on M&A) |url=http://businessthinker.com/preliminary-due-diligence-this-is-the-8th-article-in-the-series-on-ma/|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Due Diligence in mergers and acquisition|url=http://www.accountingcpd.net/Due_Diligence_in_Mergers_and_Acquisitions_by_Peter_Howson|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> Executives may be so interested in a deal that they ignore identified risks and move ahead—and later suffer from management issues.<ref name="Main steps"/> Information gathering can involve interviewing the management team, but the team may see them as expensive and time-consuming.<ref name="What is"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Interviews|url=http://compass.port.ac.uk/UoP/file/d8a7aedc-be56-461b-85e8-ae38ccf49670/1/Interviews_IMSLRN.zip/page_03.htm|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> People doing the analysis might not be familiar with the organization's sector, which can lead to wrong conclusions.<ref name="most important"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
